contentrichtext.text: {{no footnotes|date=February 2013}} The ancient Greek word ''aithôn'' means "burning", "blazing" or "shining." Less strictly, it can denote the colour red-brown, or "tawny." <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3D%232363 |title=A Greek-English Lexicon |last1=Liddell |first1=Henry George |last2=Scott |first2=Robert |date=1940 |website=Perseus Digital Library |publisher=Clarendon Press |accessdate=5 July 2013}}</ref> It is an epithet sometimes applied to animals such as horses at Hom. ''Il''. 2.839 ; oxen at ''Od''.18.372; and an eagle at ''Il''. 15.690 (cf. [[Hyginus]]' calling the eagle that tormented [[Prometheus]] an ''aethonem aquilam'' at ''Fabulae'' 31.5.)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hs-augsburg.de/~harsch/Chronologia/Lspost02/Hyginus/hyg_fabu.html |title=Hygini genealogiis, volgo fabulae |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |website=Bibliotheca Augustana |publisher= |accessdate=5 July 2013 |language= Latin |trans_title=}}</ref> In [[Greek mythology|Greek]] and [[Roman mythology]] there are a number of characters known as '''Aethon'''. Most are horses, variously belonging to: * [[Helios]] ([[Ovid]], ''[[Metamorphoses]]'' 2.153) * [[Ares]] ([[Quintus Smyrnaeus]], ''Posthomerica'' 8.239) * [[Hector]] ([[Homer]], ''[[Iliad]]'' 8.184) * [[Pallas (son of Evander)|Pallas]] ([[Vergil]], ''[[Aeneid]]'' 11.89) The name is twice applied to humans. In ''[[Odyssey]]'' 19.183, it is the pseudonym a disguised [[Odysseus]] assumes during his interview with [[Penelope]] upon his return to [[Ithaca]]. According to fr. 43a.5 of [[Hesiod]]'s ''[[Catalogue of Women]]'', [[Erysichthon of Thessaly|Erysichthon]] was also known as Aethon due to the "burning" hunger (''aithôn limos'') he was made to endure by [[Demeter]] (cf. [[Callimachus]]' ''Hymn to Demeter'' 6.65ff.)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theoi.com/Heros/Erysikhthon.html |title=Erysikhthon |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Theoi Greek Mythology |publisher= |accessdate=5 July 2013}}</ref> ==References== <references/> {{Greek-myth-stub}} [[Category:Personification in Greek mythology]] [[Category:Roman mythology]] [[Category:Greek gods]] [[Category:Legendary birds]] [[Category:Mythological horses]] [[es:Limos]] [[fr:Fames]] [[lt:Aetonas]] [[pt:Limos]]
